headline: Mississippi Pot Roast
description: Mississippi pot roast is easy to make in a slow cooker with a chuck roast, au jus gravy, and pepperoncini peppers for fork-tender, flavorsome results.

video.description: In this video, Nicole shows you how to make the famous Mississippi pot roast with some gravy and mashed potatoes for a classy southern style meal.
video.name: How to Make Mississippi Pot Roast

name: Mississippi Pot Roast
recipeIngredient: 1 (1 ounce) packet au jus gravy mix
1 (0.4 oz) package buttermilk ranch dressing mix
salt and ground black pepper to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Combine chuck roast, pepperoncini, pepperoncini juice, butter, au jus mix, ranch dressing mix, salt, and pepper in a slow cooker. Cover and cook on Low until roast is fork-tender, about 8 hours.
Remove chuck from slow cooker; shred with 2 forks and serve with gravy.

review.reviewBody: Usually when I make a roast I use a bunch of different seasonings. Thought I'd try this. It was ok and obviously easy, but I'll go back to the way I usually season it.

Freakishly easy — but also freakishly salty due to the high sodium in the gravy and ranch packets! I have seen a packet now that’s called Mississippi Roast and combines the ingredients — maybe having just one packet will cut down on the salt. Keep in mind the pepperoncini juice is also salty. I recommend unsalted butter, at least.
Added potatoes and carrots. Tangy with Little kick. SOOOOOOO GOOOOOOD
Outstanding. Roast was very tender. Only change was used 1/4 cup of butter and 1/2 cup of beef stock. Definitely make again
Excellent! This is better than regular pot roast....the tang from the peperoncinis is just right! We preferred the "gravy" to be thinner - more like au jus....and went light on it. A winner for sure!
I made it just just as listed but added a little beef broth and wine for more gravy. It was a big hit with my wife. It was really good!
I love making this, sometimes I use rice with it, sometimes I use mashed potatoes, my favorite cut up potatoes and cook with this recipe.
This is the BEST recipe! Never fails me .So easy and the flavor is sooo delicious! Give it a try!!

Love it, I will be making my roast this way from now on. The only change I made was only using 1/2 a package of brown gravy instead of au jus (it is too salty) and 4 to 5 pepperoncini peppers. And1/2 cup butter. I omitted the salt and pepper. This being the second time I made it, I added onion, celery and potatoes. It was delicious.

I love this recipe. But the meat never comes out very tender for me. I use a chuck roast, I also cook on low for 7-8 hours. So it's very frustrating when the meat isn't tender and I can't shred or cut with just a fork. But at least it always tastes good!
Made this almost like the recipe but instead, I used a cross rib roast. Really tasty piled on some mashed potatoes and fed the whole bunch.. Homemade bread too..

This is the most tender pot roast I have ever made !!! I’m not much on those peppers in the past, but it’s the juice that makes it yummy. Wasn’t sure to store the juice with the pot roast, so I put them in separate containers. Will definitely be making this again ☺️
The most tender roast ever! Yummo!
It is a super easy recipe. It's so good. Great for set & forget while on an outing while camping.

I have made this so many times. I have also made it with a Pork roast. OMG game changer!! There's a difference in the taste (pork taste better to me). Both taste amazing but the budget friendly cost of pork vs beef and still taste amazing!
I've made this a few times. I only add a half stick of butter and I add mushrooms and sliced onions. I use some of the broth to make my rice and the rest for gravy. My family loves it!
followed the recipes exactly and was the toughest toast i’ve had in 40 yrs
An easy & super flavorful meal!! I've made it a few times, and love it easy time :-)
This was so good! So much flavor! I had mine without bread, but my husband put his on a hoagie with provolone and was obsessed.

Was not so sure about this one…..but took the chance and made it… my house smelled amazing all day…it was easy… and when it was done it was delicious….will make it again for sure…. And my neighbors will be happy…. As they got the leftovers)!
I absolutely loved it! It was fast and easy , yet healthy and hearty with mashed potatoes on the side 🤩
Winner every time I make it

My family really likes this pot roast recipe a lot, but it is rather salty. I use only half of each packet and only half a stick of butter to cut down greasiness. (The flavor is still there even with these changes.) My recipe calls for 6 pepperoncini and doesn’t call for the juice, so I’ve never added it. We always want more gravy, for serving with mashed potatoes, so after reading reviews here, next time I make it, I’ll remove the roast after cooking and make a cornstarch/flour slurry and add beef broth to make additional gravy. Super easy prep (I do not sear first) and nice to come home to the house smelling wonderful and dinner almost ready!

I just made this the other day. I could not use both dry packages as it added so much sodium!! 46% sodium is just way too high!! It tasted fine but not much different than any other pot roast. I won’t make it again

Love this recipe! The only change I make is to use butter powder instead of a stick of butter as the chuck roast adds plenty of fat to the broth. I have also used Better than Bouillon instead of the au jus packet at times, still tasty as ever.

Easiest pot roast ever. Works well as a base dish that can be modified according to taste. I once picked up Italian dressing mix instead of Ranch, and it was great. Also add 1 Tbsp. of corn starch and 1 cup of beef broth to the juices, after roast is removed, to make gravy.
Didn't change a thing and it was fantastic. A keeper!
I love this recipe. It is now a staple in my house. So easy and my family asks for it. I make it as printed except I use the instant pot instead of crock pot. 5 stars
Needs onions!
Absolutely flavorful! Served on toasted ciabatta rolls with havarti cheese! Amazing! Love this recipe!
I have also made this with pork roast and it is absolutely delicious. My family like the pork better than the beef roast.
We love it!! I have made it several times and its the most tender and flavorful roast I believe I have ever had!
We all disliked it. It was too spicy and too pickled. Absolutely awful.

3rd time making it, Gluten Free. I just substituted beef broth concentrates for AuJus package and diluted it with a bit more juice from the pepperoncini. This recipe is the easiest thing you will ever make! Men love it, I never have left overs!
Perfectly delicious 😋
I made it as the recipe was... Loved it! Mashed potatoes, steamed carrots and a salad, were great sides with it! Will definitely make it again!
I love this recipe, very easy to make and it tastes great. It also is tender. I will make this again because my family loves it!
This pot roast is amazing. Only thing I did different was added mushrooms and a little more beef stock because we love gravies. Loved it!
I make this quite often for my family. I add potatoes, carrots, celery and onions to the crackpot as well. Simple ans delicious one pot meal.

I’ve made it several times myself and it’s pretty good. This last time I’ve made it, I used jalapeños instead, added some minced garlic, a stick of butter, and a little bock style beer. And as other mentioned, I sear the meat to lock in the flavor and prevent it from drying out prior to putting it in the crockpot.

I didn't have pepperoncini or au jus gravy so I used yellow Pepper rings and juice and a brown gravy packet instead, followed the rest of the recipe and this had to be the best Pot Roast we have ever eaten. My husband and I fought over the left overs the next day. Will be making this from now on. I might even try it with the correct ingredients.
Sooooo easy!!!! Salty and delicious. I used the same recipe, but it called for the addition of butter. I’ve eaten it with rice, green beans and potatoes. They all go well. Again, so easy!
Loved it

This was a very pleasant surprise! I am usually disappointed with slow cooker meals but still cook them with busy evening schedules. I ended up having to cook this in the instant pot instead of the slow cooker due to timing. One hour on high pressure and it was perfect. I did end up adding a bit of beef broth with the pepperocini juice since I was using the instant pot otherwise I followed the recipe. Highly recommend!

The only changes I made were that I did not add salt & pepper, thankfully! We found that it the addition of the pepperocini juice made it much too salty for our taste. Other than that, I followed the instructions exactly. I did end up adding sour cream which toned down the saltiness and it was very good. We ate it in a low carb flour tortilla with grated cheese and the sour cream. If I make it again, I will probably use the 1/2 jar of pepperocini that is still in the jar and then add bone broth and toss the juice down the drain.
Followed to the "T" the first time making it. Added half a stick of butter to the top of the roast and 4 cloves of garlic the second time. Awesome!

I used a 4 lb. Chuck roast rather than a 3 lb. I did not salt the roast and just seasoned it with pepper. I also used 1 C. of low sodium chicken broth and 6 oz. of the pepperoncini juice and approx. 10 pepperoncini peppers. I cooked in my slow cooker on high for 10 hrs. I removed the roast to a plate and lightly covered for 15 min. while I mixed a rouge of flour and juice from roast added back to the slow cooker to slightly thicken. It was SO darn tender and juicy with the most AWESOME flavor! Next time (and there will definitely be a next time) I will double the gravy ingredients. My brother compared the gravy to liquid gold!
This is a great recipe EXCEPT, too many peppers!! You only need about 4-5, otherwise it is way too salty.

It was so quick and easy to put together. The roast & gravy was sooo good. Had quite a kick spice-wise, my 11-year old grandson thought it was a bit spicy but still ate it. Next time I’d like a little less spicy peppercini’s, if they exist. I’ll make this many more times.
Always a fan favorite

I made it just as the recipe stated but added a little red wine. We had it the first night with mashed potatoes & it was fabulous. The next day we had the leftovers on toasted steak rolls a la Italian Beef sandwiches. I'm definitely going to make it again & again & again! TOO easy and great results!

Made exactly as recipe except did add 1/2 stick unsalted butter on top per other reviews. We ate it on tortillas cause there was no juice after shredding. We all love spicy but it was really dry. Do have to say it's much better the next day. Glad I tried it but gonna have to go back to my regular roast in crockpot per family requests.

I made this on a whim and it was good! My husband not a fan of ranch but trust me, you do not know it's in there. Good flavor. I had to cook a lot longer as didn't dear it and yes got a bit tough, so I cut it up and let it cook longer. I will try with potatoes next time :)
The Ranch Dressing had no buttermilk in it. Do you need to add liquid or powdered buttermilk?

I used 1/2 package of Lipton Onion soup mix instead of the au jus package. I followed the rest of the recipe as written. We didn't like it because it tasted like the peppers and little else. The meat was tender so I will make it again with some beef broth instead of the peppers and juice, along with the other ingredients.

My husband is the only person in our family that likes roast. I never make it. So when this recipe came across my feed I thought I would try it. This is excellent, so much flavor. Everyone ate and enjoyed. Loved that it was not big chunks of meat with vegetables. Thank you for sharing!! I did season with Kinder’s Prime Rib seasoning and added a stick of butter 4 hrs in. Not sure that it needed it though.
This recipe makes a great roast. It's a family favorite. We prefer it with pork roast, rather than beef. We usually serve it with garlic mashed potatoes and baby carrots.

The recipe I have for this also calls for browning the roast, a stick of unsalted butter on top, and no added pickling juice so that's what I do. I also use sliced mild banana peppers instead of the pepperoncini for the more delicate tummies in our family! :-) Turns out tender and oh so yummy!

We've made this a few times and love it. It is a bit more kid friendly of you reduce the number of Pepperoncini to just three or four uncut whole ones. The last time we used a healthy portion of cut Pepperoncini and our five kids wouldn't eat it even though they had gobbled it up in the past.
Loved this and so simple and easy.

I've been using this recipe for about 5 years, so quick and easy to dump it in in the morning and have a delicious meal ready when you get home! I usually add about a cup of red cooking wine just to give the broth in the bottom even more dimension. Try it!

Well, here goes. Incidentally, I hate people who do this. I am not a veggies guy (shameful, I know, but it is what it is). That's what I don't like about most pot roasts; they are loaded with veggies. However, I love Italian Beef and IB sandwiches! I made this recipe the first time as directed. Quite good, and the peppers and juice added a kind of mild Italian flavor, which I liked. Intrigued by some of the other reviews, I bought another USDA Choice chuck roast (4 lbs), seared it, put it in the crock pot on top of whole carrots and quartered onions, added the peppers, juice, butter and my own au jus and ranch recipes (found here on AR), and cooked on low for 7 hours. I removed the meat, strained out all of the veggies, added 1/2 tsp each of Maggie Seasoning (red top) and aged balsamic vinegar to the remaining jus and prepared a flour gravy from the combination. I sliced part of the beef and served it with the gravy, mashed potatoes, a side of spinach (I do like spinach) with butter and sherry vinegar, and a vinegarette side salad. It was a great Sunday dinner! I shredded the rest of the beef for hot beef sandwiches and French dip sandwiches. It lasted less than one week! I give the original recipe 4 stars, but it provably should be 5.

This can also be made using a pork roast, which is how I've made it. Also, a stick of butter is in the recipe I use. My recipe also says a packet of onion soup mix instead of the aux ju, but that's not a do or die.

I pat the roast down and sear it really good in a skillet with salt, pepper and garlic powder before putting it the pot. Instead of cutting the pepperoncinis, I buy the Deli-style so they're already thinly sliced. I also add a package of Lipton Onion Soup Mix and one thinly sliced white onion, and a half a cup of beef broth. You MUST put a whole stick of real butter (not margarine) on top of everything before putting the lid on. When it's done cooking, I take the chuck roast out and add cornstarch and water to make a nice thick gravy--it's absolutely mouth-watering, melt in your mouth, delicious. Serve it with buttery mashed potatoes, rice, or creamy polenta! I've made it at least 10-12 times, and my guests go crazy over it!
Just added a stick of butter
It was wonderful. Used mild pepperoncini this time, last time did med but was too hot. I also used dry onion soup mix instead on au jus. Sooo good, everyone loved it
Everyone loved so tender

I let it sit overnight in the refrigerator after cooking so the fat would congeal on top, makes it very easy to skim the fat off and you can control how much fat you leave in but if you're worried about the fat and fat calories, you can get rid of as much as you want.

I have made this, many times, and family loves it. Added veggies detract from the flavor, IMO, and I always cook or roast them separatly. Also, the Au Jus and Ranch mixes have a LOT of salt in them, so don't add any more to it. I did, the first time and almost couldn't eat it. It really does not need the juice from the pepperoncini, and you can eliminate it, if you want to.

I wasn't expecting such a difference from the way I usually make a roast. I'll never make a roast any other way - sooo delicious! I roasted my potatoes and carrots in the oven after another review mentioned it would be a mistake. Terrific recipe.
This is so good. As others have suggested, I serve it on a bun with provolone (or muenster) cheese and extra banana peppers. It's such a delicious option for a roast.

I love this recipe, and it’s the only pot roast I have ever really liked. With that said, I forgot to put it in. This morning and didn’t get it into the pot until 2:30. I put it on high and added some beef stock, thinking that might help keep it from drying out. How long should I cook it on high? Would it be 3/4 hours. vs. 8 hours on low?
Made roast as per recipe. It was so salty and I added water and still was salty. The recipe idea is very good and tasty. I will try this again.
My family LOVED this simple but flavorful recipe. I accidentally used all the liquid instead of 1/2 and it still turned out great! Enjoy!
This is the best pot roast recipe we’ve tried. My husband loves it.

Ever since I found this recipe several years ago this is the ONLY way I will cook a pot roast. It's amazing. So tender it falls apart. Great flavor and it's not spicy hot. It's just delicious. By the way, this is the only review I've ever written and I'm constantly trying new recipes from this site. I strongly encourage you to try this recipe!!

Nope. This dish was definitely not for us. It smelled wonderful when it was cooking, and it certainly wasn't lacking in flavor, but it was far too spicy for us. I tried to subdue it by serving it over a bed of extra wide noodles, but it still bit back. 
My husband did not finish his meal because he could already feel the heartburn building. One thing I will say about the recipe is: I held back on adding any salt and pepper to the dish, and I was glad I did. The ranch dressing and au jus packets had more than enough salt (almost too much) and, thanks to the pepperoncini, the dish did not require any additional pepper. I will not be making this dish again.

I have made the NYT version of this before and found it quite tasty, although too buttery and without the pepperoncini. I was looking forward to making it again. I make it pretty much according to directions but it came out SALTY. The sauce was inedible. I think it was all due to the pepperoncini. I added a very small bit of salt in the beginning, on the roast itself and only on one side. Definitely not enough to cause this level of saltiness. I am nibbling on the leftovers right now and the salt is definitely coming from the peppers. The meat by itself is fine. I'll make this again because it is so convenient but I don't think i'll add the peppers anymore.
I have been making this at least once a month with the exception of adding potatoes and onions and mushrooms. I ABSOLUTELY love this meal.
This is my go-to recipe for slow cooker meat. You can do chicken or pork chops (so tasty) with this recipe and it is so easy and so good!!
My family loved it so much I'm going to have to double the recipe next time!!! It was so easy to make!!
super easy and super good

I was hesitant bc I usually steer clear of packets, but this was divine! I planned on using the crockpot but had to adapt it to the Instant Pot in a pinch. It came out perfect! I used one full stick of unsalted Kerrygold butter as others suggested, Knorr brand Au Jus packet—you’ll need two in order to get 1oz (I used a food scale), Hidden Valley Brand for the buttermilk ranch, 4lbs of roast (after trimming) cut into large chunks, and 1/2 cup of beef bone broth (what I had). I had to add the broth bc I needed 1 full cup of liquid for pressure cooking. The pepperocini liquid was only 1/2 cup. I think the salt ratio was perfect with the 4lbs of meat. Highly recommend with the Steakhouse Potatoes Romanoff recipe on here!

This has wonderful flavor. My family has requested this be added to our menu rotation. 
I made this with a 5 lbs. roast, with all the seasonings except the salt and pepper. This turned out way too salty! Next time, I will decrease the amount of ranch dressing mix.

The meat becomes fork tender and was delicious. Can see using a tougher cut of beef for this. But, OMG, this is SO salty!!! We don't ordinarily cook with salt and we were both shocked by the salty taste. I'll make it again because the roast was so tender. But next time, I'll use low sodium gravy and dressing (and peppers, if I can find them.)

I've made this a few times following this recipe exactly, other than not adding any extra salt Can't say it's not easy or tasty. It's just always too, too salty. 
 Now, I add a chopped onion and some celery, as well as some new potatoes to dilute the saltiness. It's still salty, but not quite as much.

This is not your typical Sunday pot roast. The juice from the peperoncini peppers does a great job of adding flavour and tenderizing the meat as well. This is not your typical Sunday pot roast. Some have said that they added potatoes and carrots. Would not recommend it as the flavour is off and not enough liquid for those starchy vegetables. I did add about 4 oz of sliced white mushrooms. Also, could not find any Au Jui mix so I used some French onion soup mix instead. Worked great. Had family turn on the slow cooker about 9:30 and when I got home around 5:30 roast was done. All I had to do was prepare vegetables. Turned out perfect. Have made it several times and would do so again.

I make this in double batches so I can always have some in the freezer. I shred mine when done. I’ve served it for breakfast over cubed potatoes with sunny side up eggs on top, on a bun with slaw on top, as is with a side veggie or salad. Easy to make, perfectly flavored, and oh so good.

Amazing - I have made this several times and it comes out perfect. I do sear the meat, added the pepperoncini, juice, ranch mix and gravy mix and that is it! 8 hours later, done to perfection....I sliced mine and kept it warm; added a cornstarch slurry to thicken the gravy. So good I've passed along this recipe to family and friends. Thank you...

The only thing I add to this recipe is a stick of butter. Cut the butter into tablespoon servings, line the bottom of the slow cooker with half of the stick, then top the roast with the other half of the stick of butter.

This recipe is amazing! I've made it twice now and it was so easy and tasty. The first time I made it as written in the recipe and it was delicious! The second time I seared the roast before adding it to the crockpot and added half a stick of butter on top as suggested in other reviews. It was so good! I will definitely be making it again.

Chef John makes a from scratch version of this (Mississippi Beef Short Ribs) and while I am a big fan of his and cooking from scratch, I preferred this. I could not find au jus mix so used jarred and cut down on the pepperoncini pepper juice, which was a good call anyway as that would have been too spicy for us. I used stew beef, dredged the cubes in flour, seared on two sides, placed in crock pot, combined the rest of the ingredients in the pan and brought it to simmer before adding it to the crock pot. Like I always do, I put the crockpot on High until the contents came to a simmer before turning down to Low. This way I can prep at lunch and the meal is ready for dinner.

This was absolutely delicious, and my husband called it scary good! I love that it was so fast and easy to make and was in the crock pot cooking in 5 minutes! Most Mississippi Pot Roasts include butter so I did add half a stick. This recipe is high in sodium so I used a smaller packet of the gravy mix to cut back a bit.
It was absolutely delicious. My family loved it and it is so easy to make yet tastes impressive

Hands down the best kielbasa and cabbage recipe I’ve ever made. The only change I made is that I browned the onions while cooking the bacon and didn’t add caraway because I didn’t have and am not a big fan anyway. Delish!
The flavor was unique and great, all my dinner guests enjoyed the dish. But I pressure cooked it and the next time I will slow cook it, so it winds up stringy and tender.

Could only find a 16 oz. jar of peperoncini so I had to estimate. I may have added a little more than called for but the roast was delicious! Even my picky roommate loved it. Will definitely make this again!
So simple and so amazingly good! I skipped the salt and added a bag of frozen mixed veggies the last hour of cooking. Will definitely be making again!

Great recipe. Definitely sear the meat on all sides first. I seared my in a small amount of lard in a cast iron pan. Then carmelized sliced onions in the pan drippings and added them to the slow cooker. I also took the advice of others and added a stick of butter on top of the roast in the slow cooker. The result was amazing!
